content:
I was idly thinking about endofunctors on FinSet\bf FinSetFinSet. At first I conjectured that they are all polynomial functors (i.e. coproducts of representables), but I quickly realised this is wrong, because there is a powerset functor FinSet→FinSet\bf FinSet\to FinSetFinSet→FinSet. This maps nnn-element sets to 2n2^n2n-element sets, and 2n2^n2n isn't polynomial in nnn.

This made me wonder what other functions are possible. In particular, is there an endofunctor on FinSet\bf FinSetFinSet that maps nnn-element sets to F(n)F(n)F(n)-element setes, where F:N→NF:\N\to\NF:N→N is an uncomputable function, such as the busy beaver function?

Or more broadly, is there an endofunctor on the skeleton of FinSet\bf FinSetFinSet that is incomputable, in the sense that there is no Turing machine that can determine the image of every morphism?

It feels like the constraint of functoriality might be strong enough to prevent this from existing, but I might just not be hitting on the right counterexample.

Can one diagonalise over all computable endofunctors of FInSet? That is, something like take n↦P(Fn(n))n\mapsto P(F_n(n))n↦P(Fn​(n)), where FnF_nFn​ is the nthn^{th}nth computable endofunctor, assuming they are countable?
How would such a diagonal functor act on morphisms?
I seems helpful to think of such a functor as a symmetric set, which is a simplicial set with extra symmetries that amount to reordering the vertices of each simplex.

Based on this, it should be possible to consider functors that are constant 111 on any set of cardinality <n< n<n, such as taking a representable and identifying all its simplices in dimensions d<nd < nd<n. Topologically, this is an nnn-sphere.
Then by taking coproducts of these, you can achieve arbitrarily fast growth, and in particular the map n↦∣F([n])∣n \mapsto |F([n])|n↦∣F([n])∣ can be uncomputable.
I'm getting a little mixed up by extrapolating my understanding of simplicial sets to symmetric sets, so take the details with a grain of salt.

Nathaniel Virgo said:

How would such a diagonal functor act on morphisms?

Good point. This would only be sensible on the core of FinSet, perhaps.

I'm having trouble seeing how Toby's sort of functor FFF achieves arbitrarily large growth while remaining finite for all finite sets. If F(S)F(S)F(S) is huge for some large set SSS and f:S→Tf: S \to Tf:S→T maps SSS to a smaller set TTT we need F(f)F(f)F(f) to be highly many-to-one, or else F(T)F(T)F(T) will also be huge.

For this reason it's proving much easier for me to invent uncomputable functors F:core(FinSet)→FinSetF: \mathrm{core}(\mathsf{FinSet}) \to \mathsf{FinSet}F:core(FinSet)→FinSet than uncomputable functors F:FinSet→FinSetF: \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}F:FinSet→FinSet.
However, there must exist lots of uncomputable functors F:FinSet→FinSetF: \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}F:FinSet→FinSet, simply because there are only countably many computable ones!

I agree, I'm having trouble with that too :sweat_smile: so all I want to suggest is that thinking of it in topological terms of symmetric simplicial sets may be helpful for constructing examples of functors that take small values on small sets and really large values on larger sets.
How can we prove that there are uncountably many endofunctors on FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet? It seems "obvious" but I don't immediately see how to prove it.
Oh no, I even got confused about the variance :woozy_face: no more math before breakfast!

John Baez said:

How can we prove that there are uncountably many endofunctors on FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet? It seems "obvious" but I don't immediately see how to prove it.

For every object XXX of a category, defines the endofunctor 1X1_X1X​ by 1X(A)=X1_X(A)=X1X​(A)=X and 1X(f)=idX1_X(f)=\mathrm{id}_X1X​(f)=idX​.

The collection {1{x}:FinSet→FinSet, x∈R}\{1_{\{x\}}:\mathbf{FinSet} \rightarrow \mathbf{FinSet},~x \in \mathbb{R}\}{1{x}​:FinSet→FinSet, x∈R} is an uncountable collection of endofunctors of FinSet\mathbf{FinSet}FinSet.

Of course, these endofunctors should be isomorphic for a good definition of morphism of endofunctors. So we should find an uncountable collection of non isomorphic sets if you want a solution in the stronger sense using these constant endofunctors. I don’t know much about cardinals but I think that it would boil down to proving that the collection of all cardinals is uncountable. Maybe this assertion is false, I don’t know.

For this story of constant endofunctors, it might be helpful to realize that every category is isomorphic to the full subcategory of constant endofunctors of its category of endofunctors (a natural transformation from the constant endofunctor 1X1_X1X​ to the constant endofunctor 1Y1_Y1Y​ is always a natural transformation 1f:1X→1Y1_f:1_X \rightarrow 1_Y1f​:1X​→1Y​ given by (1f)(A)=f:X=1X(A)→Y=1Y(A)(1_f)(A)=f:X=1_X(A) \rightarrow Y=1_Y(A)(1f​)(A)=f:X=1X​(A)→Y=1Y​(A) for some f:X→Yf:X \rightarrow Yf:X→Y). So that the category of endofunctors of a category is always bigger than the category. In particular there is an injection of the set of objects of a category into the set of object of its category of endofunctors. So if ObC\mathrm{Ob}_\mathcal{C}ObC​ is uncountable, then ObEnd(C)\mathrm{Ob}_{\mathrm{End}(\mathcal{C})}ObEnd(C)​ is uncountable.

One then has to worry whether the natural isomorphism between a computable endofunctor and an arbitrary one is computable, but I think if your endofunctor is constant, it should be computable. And if the constant object is has no nontrivial endomorphisms then any two such constant functors taking _values_ that are isomorphic, they are uniquely isomorphic, and so the natural isomorphism is also constant. And so that should be computable, too.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

John Baez said:

How can we prove that there are uncountably many endofunctors on FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet? It seems "obvious" but I don't immediately see how to prove it.

The collection {1{x}:FinSet→FinSet, x∈R}\{1_{\{x\}}:\mathbf{FinSet} \rightarrow \mathbf{FinSet},~x \in \mathbb{R}\}{1{x}​:FinSet→FinSet, x∈R} is an uncountable collection of endofunctors of FinSet\mathbf{FinSet}FinSet.

Haha! True, but this is like asking a genie "make me a milkshake" - and then he turns you into a milkshake. :smirk:

I should have asked: can anyone find uncountably many natural isomorphism classes of endofunctors of FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet?

Or equivalently: if F\mathsf{F}F is a skeleton of FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet, can anyone find uncountably many endofunctors of F\mathsf{F}F?
I think we should be talking about the skeleton of FinSet\bf FinSetFinSet if we want to talk about computability anyway
It makes life simpler, for sure.

John Baez said:

How can we prove that there are uncountably many endofunctors on FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet? It seems "obvious" but I don't immediately see how to prove it.

Surprisingly, there aren't.
For a locally finite category CCC (I.e. such that homsets are finite), [Cop,FinSet][C^{\mathrm{op}},\mathrm{FinSet}][Cop,FinSet] is the free finitary cocompletion of CCC; all of its objects are naturally isomorphic to a finite colimit of representables by the coYoneda lemma. Taking CCC to be the opposite of the category of finite sets, we obtain that every endofunctor of finite sets is a finite colimit of representables!!
Wow, amazing - yet simple in retrospect!
(And there are countably many since there are countably many isomorphism classes of finite diagram)

So now I've completely flip-flopped: it now seems "obvious" that every endofunctor of FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet is computable - or if that concept seems too murky, every endofunctor on the skeleton F\mathsf{F}F of FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet with objects {},{0},{0,1},...\{\}, \{0\}, \{0,1\}, ... {},{0},{0,1},... is computable.
That's because I believe a finite colimit of representable functors on Fop\mathsf{F}^{\textrm{op}}Fop is computable.
It takes a bit of work to define when a functor f:F→Ff: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}f:F→F is "representable", though... and now I'm getting confused about this.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

Taking CCC to be the opposite of the category of finite sets, we obtain that every endofunctor of finite sets is a finite colimit of representables!!

Wait, what? Where did I go wrong initially, then? Can the covariant power set functor be expressed as a finite colimit of representables in FinSet\bf FinSetFinSet?
I don't immediately see the answer to your question, Nathaniel, so you may be on to something, but Morgan is talking about representable functors on FinSetop\mathsf{FinSet}^{\textrm{op}}FinSetop.

This is fairly confusing! A representable functor on FinSetop\mathsf{FinSet}^{\textrm{op}}FinSetop is a functor of the form

FinSetop(−,x):(FinSetop)op→Set \mathsf{FinSet}^{\textrm{op}}(-,x) : (\mathsf{FinSet}^{\textrm{op}})^{\textrm{op}} \to \mathsf{Set} FinSetop(−,x):(FinSetop)op→Set

for some x∈FinSetopx \in \mathsf{FinSet}^{\textrm{op}} x∈FinSetop. This is a convoluted way of saying a functor

FinSet(x,−):(FinSet→Set\mathsf{FinSet}(x,-) : (\mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{Set} FinSet(x,−):(FinSet→Set

for some x∈FinSetopx \in \mathsf{FinSet}^{\textrm{op}} x∈FinSetop.
The point must be that the colimit can still be infinite: an infinite coproduct, plus infinitely many identifications that result in the colimit functor still taking finite values.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

Surprisingly, there aren't.
For a locally finite category CCC (I.e. such that homsets are finite), [Cop,FinSet][C^{\mathrm{op}},\mathrm{FinSet}][Cop,FinSet] is the free finitary cocompletion of CCC; all of its objects are naturally isomorphic to a finite colimit of representables by the coYoneda lemma.

In other words, why is the colimit necessarily finite?

So you're claiming this is false, @Tobias Fritz:

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

For a locally finite category CCC (I.e. such that homsets are finite), [Cop,FinSet][C^{\mathrm{op}},\mathrm{FinSet}][Cop,FinSet] is the free finitary cocompletion of CCC; all of its objects are naturally isomorphic to a finite colimit of representables by the coYoneda lemma.

Yes, for a simpler counterexample just take CCC to be a category having infinitely many objects and only identity morphisms. Then the finite colimits of representables are only those functors that take almost all objects to the empty set.

Right. Okay. So I no longer believe Morgan's argument that there are only countably many endofunctors on FinSet, up to natural isomorphism. He just stated his claim with such conviction that I was bowled over.

So I still don't know if there are uncountably many endofunctors on FinSet, up to natural isomorphism. :cry:

Tobias Fritz said:

I seems helpful to think of such a functor as a symmetric set, which is a simplicial set with extra symmetries that amount to reordering the vertices of each simplex.

I still think that this is a good way of constructing examples of fast-growing functors FinSetop→FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}^\mathrm{op} \to \mathsf{FinSet}FinSetop→FinSet, which can then be composed with the contravariant power set functor to get examples of fast-growing functors FinSet→FinSet\mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}FinSet→FinSet.

Here's a concrete example inspired by that and which is also in the spirit of species. Fix k∈Nk \in \mathbb{N}k∈N, and for a finite set AAA let Fk(A)F_k(A)Fk​(A) be the set of kkk-uniform hypergraphs with vertex set AAA. Here, a kkk-uniform hypergraph is a subset of the set of kkk-element subsets of AAA, and I'm using these because there's only one kkk-uniform hypergraph structure on a set with fewer than kkk elements. This FkF_kFk​ can easily be made into a functor: for f:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B and a kkk-hypergraph structure H∈Fk(A)H \in F_k(A)H∈Fk​(A), we can say that a subset S⊆BS \subseteq BS⊆B belongs to the transported hypergraph structure Fk(f)(H)F_k(f)(H)Fk​(f)(H) on BBB if and only if f−1(S)f^{-1}(S)f−1(S) contains a subset belonging to HHH. In terms of drawing hypergraphs, you just map hyperedges to hyperedges and discard those for which fff identifies vertices.

The upshot now is that Fk(A)F_k(A)Fk​(A) is singleton precisely for ∣A∣<k|A| < k∣A∣<k. So by taking finite colimits of these functors, one can achieve arbitrarily large growth, and in particular uncomputable growth. It also shows that there are uncountably many (isomorphism classes) of endofunctors.

So let's see if I get this right. You're claiming that:

1) There's a functor Fk:FinSet→FinSetF_k: \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}Fk​:FinSet→FinSet such that on objects Fk(A)=P(Pk(A))F_k(A) = P(P_k(A))Fk​(A)=P(Pk​(A)) where:

  • Pk(A)P_k(A)Pk​(A) is the set of kkk-element subsets of AAA

and

  • P(S)P(S)P(S) is the power set of SSS.

2) Fk(A)F_k(A)Fk​(A) has just one element if ∣A∣<k|A| \lt k∣A∣<k.
Yep, that's a good way to put it. Note that 2) is a consequence of 1) because of P(Pk(A))=P(∅)=1P(P_k(A)) = P(\emptyset) = 1P(Pk​(A))=P(∅)=1 if ∣A∣<k|A| < k∣A∣<k.

Okay, great. The only thing I'm worrying about is how FkF_kFk​ is defined on morphisms. You explained it, but... is it the composite of some covariant functors PPP and PkP_kPk​ that are defined on objects as I said, and defined somehow on morphisms? Or maybe is it the composite of two contravariant functors PPP and PkP_kPk​ that are defined on objects as I said?

I don't yet know how to describe the action on morphisms in terms of a factorization into PkP_kPk​ and PPP, but it may be possible to do so by composing suitable versions of these functors that go Pk:FinSetop→FinRelP_k : \mathsf{FinSet}^{\mathrm{op}} \to \mathsf{FinRel}Pk​:FinSetop→FinRel and P:FinRelop→FinSetP : \mathsf{FinRel}^{\mathrm{op}} \to \mathsf{FinSet}P:FinRelop→FinSet.

The first one seems quite clear: given f:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B and a kkk-element subset S⊆BS \subseteq BS⊆B, it's related precisely to all the kkk-element subsets of f−1(S)f^{-1}(S)f−1(S), and this defines Pk(f):Pk(B)→Pk(A)P_k(f) : P_k(B) \to P_k(A)Pk​(f):Pk​(B)→Pk​(A).
In case it wasn't obvious, it's PkP_kPk​ that I'm worried about. I don't know a covariant or contravariant "kkk-element subset functor".
But if you can clearly explain to me (again?) what FkF_kFk​ does on morphisms without factoring it into two functors, that's fine too.
I've got a set SSS of kkk-element subsets of AAA, and a function f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B. I want a set of kkk-element subsets of BBB.

Actually I think the factorization works, with PkP_kPk​ as above and P:FinRelop→FinSetP : \mathsf{FinRel}^{\mathrm{op}} \to \mathsf{FinSet}P:FinRelop→FinSet the usual thing, namely taking a relation R:A→BR : A \to BR:A→B to the map P(R):P(B)→P(A)P(R) : P(B) \to P(A)P(R):P(B)→P(A) which maps every subset S⊆BS \subseteq BS⊆B to the subset of all elements of AAA that are related to something in SSS.

John Baez said:

I've got a set SSS of kkk-element subsets of AAA, and a function f:A→Bf: A \to Bf:A→B. I want a set of kkk-element subsets of BBB.

It's the set of all kkk-element subsets of BBB whose preimage contains an element of SSS as a subset.

For k=2k=2k=2, we're talking about graphs (in the combinatorialists' sense) with vertex set AAA. We can transport such a graph along fff just by pushing forward edges in the obvious way. We get into trouble for those edges whose vertices are identified under fff, but we can just ignore those.
Okay, I think it's sinking in.

So it looks like we can prove there are uncomputable functors F:F→FF: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}F:F→F (where F\mathsf{F}F is some skeleton of FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet) in at least two ways:

1) Show that there are countably many natural isomorphism classes of computable functors F:F→FF: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}F:F→F. Show there are uncountably many natural isomorphism classes of functors F:F→FF: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}F:F→F. For the latter, use functors the form

F=∑n=0∞Fk(n) F = \sum_{n = 0}^\infty F_{k(n)} F=∑n=0∞​Fk(n)​

where k:N→Nk : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}k:N→N is a strictly increasing sequence, and show that distinct such sequences give nonisomorphic functors FFF.

2) Show that if k:N→Nk : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}k:N→N is uncomputable, the functor

∑n=0∞Fk(n) \sum_{n = 0}^\infty F_{k(n)} ∑n=0∞​Fk(n)​

is uncomputable.

John Baez said:

Right. Okay. So I no longer believe Morgan's argument that there are only countably many endofunctors on FinSet, up to natural isomorphism. He just stated his claim with such conviction that I was bowled over.

I had convinced myself too, although I hadn't checked what the conditions are on a base of enrichment for the standard results such as coYoneda to work

John Baez said:

2) Show that if k:N→Nk : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}k:N→N is uncomputable, the functor

∑n=0∞Fk(n) \sum_{n = 0}^\infty F_{k(n)} ∑n=0∞​Fk(n)​

is uncomputable.

Actually the product ∏n=0∞Fk(n)\prod_{n=0}^\infty F_{k(n)}∏n=0∞​Fk(n)​ works better, because the infinite coproduct would require the functors to vanish for almost all kkk on every finite set AAA, which doesn't work because if F(A)=∅F(A) = \emptysetF(A)=∅ for some nonempty AAA, then this must hold for all nonempty AAA. But for the product on the other hand, we need Fk(A)=1F_k(A) = 1Fk​(A)=1 for almost all kkk, and this holds for example for the functors coming out of my construction with hypergraphs.

Oh, whoops - for some reason I'd been imagining Fk(A)=∅F_k(A) = \emptysetFk​(A)=∅ when ∣A∣<k|A| < k∣A∣<k, when in fact I knew it was the 1-element set. It's so easy to slip up - anyone watching this thread will see how easy.

So yes, the corrected problem set is:

1) Show that there are countably many natural isomorphism classes of computable functors F:F→FF: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}F:F→F. Show there are uncountably many natural isomorphism classes of functors F:F→FF: \mathsf{F} \to \mathsf{F}F:F→F. For the latter, use functors of the form

Fj=∏n=0∞Fk(n) F_j = \prod_{n = 0}^\infty F_{k(n)} Fj​=∏n=0∞​Fk(n)​

where j:N→Nj: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}j:N→N is a strictly increasing sequence, and show that distinct such sequences give nonisomorphic functors FjF_jFj​.

2) Show that if j:N→Nj : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}j:N→N is uncomputable, the functor FjF_jFj​ is uncomputable.

I think both of those approaches work. For 2) in particular, by taking the index sequence k(n)k(n)k(n) to grow slowly enough, we can make f(m)≔∣∏nFk(n)([m])∣f(m) \coloneqq \bigg|\prod_n F_{k(n)}([m])\bigg|f(m):=​∏n​Fk(n)​([m])​ grow faster than the busy beaver function. Now we're done because any function lower bounded by busy beaver is uncomputable: if it was computable, we could also compute the busy beaver function on mmm simply by running all mmm-state Turing machines up to time f(m)f(m)f(m).

There's still some work required to show that distinct strictly increasing sequences jjj give nonisomorphic functors FjF_jFj​, but I think this approach should be manageable, though a bit sweaty:

Compute fj,n=∣Fj{1,…,n}∣f_{j,n} = |F_j\{1, \dots, n\}|fj,n​=∣Fj​{1,…,n}∣ as a function of jjj and nnn, and then use that to show that distinct strictly increasing functions jjj give distinct sequences fj,0,fj,1,…f_{j,0}, f_{j,1}, \dotsfj,0​,fj,1​,…, hence nonisomorphic functors FjF_jFj​.
The index sequence jjj should grow slowly in order for fj,nf_{j,n}fj,n​ to grow fast in nnn, no? So it may be better to merely require jjj to be non-strictly increasing.

Tobias Fritz said:

I think both of those approaches work. For 2) in particular, by taking the index sequence j(n)j(n)j(n) to grow slowly enough, we can make f(m)≔∣∏nFj(n)([m])∣f(m) \coloneqq \bigg|\prod_n F_{j(n)}([m])\bigg|f(m):=​∏n​Fj(n)​([m])​ grow faster than the busy beaver function. Now we're done because any function lower bounded by busy beaver is uncomputable: if it was computable, we could also compute the busy beaver function on mmm simply by running all mmm-state Turing machines up to time f(m)f(m)f(m).

Okay, that would work if we take jjj to be increasing but not strictly so. I was taking jjj to be strictly increasing but that makes the argument harder (see above), since then what you're calling fff can't grow super-fast. I believe fff can still be uncomputable just by taking jjj to be uncomputable, but checking everything takes a lot more work than in your approach!
That is, I think that just by looking at fff you can figure out the sequence jjj, but it's a hassle to check this.
For your approach to work we still require that jjj eventually get larger than any fixed natural number - to make sure Fj(A)F_j(A)Fj​(A) is always finite.

It's probably possible to choose FkF_kFk​ such that the cardinalities ∣Fk(A)∣|F_k(A)|∣Fk​(A)∣ are all powers of a fixed prime depending on kkk. With these primes all chosen distinct, I think your approach of reconstructing the indexing sequence from the functor should work, most easily so if the sequence is strictly increasing.
Now you're making me imagine an alternative universe where Goedel had to encode everything as endofunctors on FinSet.

Jean-Baptiste Vienney said:

Of course, these endofunctors should be isomorphic for a good definition of morphism of endofunctors. So we should find an uncountable collection of non isomorphic sets if you want a solution in the stronger sense using these constant endofunctors. I don’t know much about cardinals but I think that it would boil down to proving that the collection of all cardinals is uncountable. Maybe this assertion is false, I don’t know.

Sorry for this, I wrote this in the middle of the night. I should have remembered that finite sets are finite. So there are only countably many finite sets up to bijection.
And that a morphism of functor is called a natural transformation :rolling_eyes:

The solution is very cool though!

EDIT: But if I understand, this candidate solution is maybe not true finally.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

(And there are countably many since there are countably many isomorphism classes of finite diagram)

This is maybe simple but how do we prove this?

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

I had convinced myself too, although I hadn't checked what the conditions are on a base of enrichment for the standard results such as coYoneda to work

I shouldn't blame you too much: I wasn't just bowing to your authority, the argument really convinced me. This is especially unfortunate because right now I'm working on a problem where the same issue comes up. It's easiest to state the issue in its decategorified form: for an infinite set XXX, there are more functions f:X→Nf: X \to \mathbb{N}f:X→N than finite sums of Kronecker delta functions. This is so obvious nobody would mix them up! But I've been dealing with FinVect\mathsf{FinVect}FinVect-valued presheaves on locally finite categories and there I keep making analogous mistakes.

So I've concluded that one needs the category to be "FinSet-small" (I.e. finite) for my original assertion about the finitary cocompletion to work, and otherwise you need to stick to finite colimits of representables for it to hold (as in Tobias' counterexample). It's a nice sandbox for thinking about size issues around the presheaf construction.

Tobias Fritz said:

It's probably possible to choose FkF_kFk​ such that the cardinalities ∣Fk(A)∣|F_k(A)|∣Fk​(A)∣ are all powers of a fixed prime depending on kkk.

And here's a way to achieve that, for any prime or general natural number ppp, based on the construction of Fk=PPkF_k = P P_kFk​=PPk​ we've discussed earlier. We just replace the 222 in the definition of the power set functor P:FinRelop→FinSetP : \mathsf{FinRel}^{\mathrm{op}} \to \mathsf{FinSet}P:FinRelop→FinSet by [p]={0,…,p−1}[p] = \{0,\dots, p-1\}[p]={0,…,p−1}, where the action on morphisms can be defined as follows: for R:A→BR : A \to BR:A→B, map a given S:B→[p]S : B \to [p]S:B→[p] to R∗S:A→[p]R^* S : A \to [p]R∗S:A→[p] defined by (R∗S)(a)=max⁡{S(b)∣aRb}(R^* S)(a) = \max \{S(b) \mid a R b\}(R∗S)(a)=max{S(b)∣aRb}.
On objects, this takes every finite set AAA to the set of maps A→[p]A \to [p]A→[p], so the cardinality is p∣A∣p^{|A|}p∣A∣.

So, to summarize:

  1. For every k∈Nk \in \mathbb{N}k∈N, there is a functor Fk:FinSet→FinSetF_k : \mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}Fk​:FinSet→FinSet such that the cardinality of every Fk(A)F_k(A)Fk​(A) is a power of the kkk-th prime, and equal to 111 if and only if ∣A∣<k|A| < k∣A∣<k.
  2. Hence for any indexing sequence k(n)k(n)k(n) with lim inf⁡n→∞k(n)=∞\liminf_{n \to \infty} k(n) = \inftyliminfn→∞​k(n)=∞, the functor F≔∏n=0∞Fk(n)F \coloneqq \prod_{n=0}^\infty F_{k(n)}F:=∏n=0∞​Fk(n)​ still lands in FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet.
  3. For any two distinct choices of strictly increasing indexing sequence, the two resulting functors are not isomorphic. Therefore there are uncountably many isomorphism classes of functors FinSet→FinSet\mathsf{FinSet} \to \mathsf{FinSet}FinSet→FinSet. In particular there are uncomputable ones.
  4. By instead making k(n)k(n)k(n) grow slowly with nnn, we can make ∣F(A)∣|F(A)|∣F(A)∣ grow arbitrarily fast with the cardinality of AAA, and in particular faster than the busy beaver function. Making such a choice gives an explicit example of an uncomputable functor. (That is as explicit as it can get, given the uncomputability.)
That's an excellent roundup of the conversation, @Tobias Fritz!
